Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Biomanufacturing: Developing a Harvesting Approach for Spatially Targeted Cells from 3D Organoids and Tissues

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: LeDuc, Philip R.
Proposal Number: 1547810

PI: Davidson, Lance A.
Proposal Number: 1547790

Cellular biomanufacturing is significant for cell and tissue-based therapies and drug testing applications. Procuring the necessary types of cells from tissues as the starting material is critical for the success of cellular biomanufacturing operations. In this application, the investigators will study a new technology that has been developed for controlling fluid flow at the micrometer scale to extract live cells from living tissues, so they can be used as building blocks for the biomanufacturing industry.

Cells most desired for biomanufacturing grow naturally within a complex heterogeneous three dimensional (3D) environment within human bodies, making their extraction very challenging. The goal of this proposal is to develop high throughput cell-harvesting approaches that allow for the controlled spatiotemporal application of reagents to 3D tissues for targeted cell extraction. To accomplish this, the investigators plan to develop a novel microfluidic harvesting approach to simultaneously image and etch phantom tissues layer-by-layer while recovering target cells downstream; and implement this microfluidics approach for use with laboratory grown organ-buds, i.e. organoids, to enable the extraction of stem cells with spatiotemporal control. The investigators will develop the ability to collect cells from defined locations within small complex 3D tissues such as organoids and use microfluidics to sort extracted cells and maintain their viability. If successful, this project will produce a significant advancement in the targeted harvesting of highly desired stem and progenitor cells from organoids and tissues with a high throughput technology that will then enable the use of recovered cells in cellular biomanufacturing as building blocks for diagnostic and therapeutic applications. The broader impacts of these studies include building an education and training pipeline for preparing future leaders in engineering and science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Imagine carrying out multiple complex medical tests on a single drop of blood or a small tissue biopsy. Such tests would need to take place at a microscopic scale and require the normally large scale processes of the lab to be shrunk down - instead of test tubes, think droplets smaller than the diameter of the human hair. The goal of microfluidics is to provide the biomedical researcher or doctor the ability to work at this microscopic scale - controlling nanoliters of fluid and observing the results of experimental tests and diagnostic assays. Innovations in microfluidics can enable small scale experiments allowing biomedical researchers new tools to investigate health critical processes on the microscale. 

The goal of this project is to develop tools for microscale analyses of health critical processes. We built our custom microfluidic devices with "soft-photolithography" tools adapted from the microchip industry. Microfluidic devices are commonly used to study single cells and even to carry out thousands of reactions at a time within small micro-droplets. Since the objective of our EAGER project was to allow hands-free microscopic dissection of tissue biopsies we had to develop new tools to manipulate tissue samples and to extend microfluidic systems to handle "larger," but still tiny, solid samples within the confines of spaces as narrow as a human hair.

During the course of this project we made the following findings:

1) To prepare samples for testing we developed methods to form and shape tissues whose narrowest dimensions complemented the dimensions of microfluidic systems. These tissues were reconstructed from dissociated cells and could be recombined into sheets as thin as 200 micrometers.

2) In order to place these samples into our devices and recover them afterwards we adapted vacuum methods to assemble multilayer devices that could be easily taken apart after tests were completed. Standard approaches to assemble multiple layer devices require irreversible bonding of the different layers to each other and to glass.

3) We developed methods to culture tissue samples in gradients of chemical treatments. Once isolated and contained in a microfluidic device we sought to develop approaches to expose tissues to gradients of activators or inhibitors of specific biological processes. Applying a gradient, where the "dose" of the treatment varies predictively across the sample replaces a large number of tests where a constant dose is applied. The variable responses of living cells to these different doses can be viewed in real-time.

Our findings are working to close a key gap to advance personalized medicine. Central to the ability of personalized medicine to deliver individualized treatments is the development of "functional" tests of living cells and tissues isolated from patients. The behaviors of living cells from a patient may inform health care providers how a patient might respond to particular drugs or treatment therapies. Microfluidics combined with small tissue biopsies are laying the foundation for these advances in personalized medicine.

The overall impact of our project has included mentoring, public lectures, new educational modules, and training PhD level students at the interface between biomedical research and engineering. This project supported two female undergraduate researchers in our group, one was awarded a Beckman Scholarship at the University of Pittsburgh and is now in Medical School at the University of Iowa, and the second will be graduating this May and is seeking an advanced degree in bioengineering and biomedical research. This project also supported PhD research by two students who have both gone on the professional scientist / analyst positions in industry. Both PhDs now work in industries that will advance personalized medicine and the application of microfluidic-based assays. Additionally, this research has been presented at numerous international and national meeting as well as through departmental seminars to audiences as diverse as developmental biologists, physicists, and applied mathematicians. Efforts have also been made to advance undergraduate coursework through the inclusion of systems and synthetic biology modules in a unique 2-semester course in Cell Biology for Bioengineering Undergraduates at the University of Pittsburgh. One new lecture module presents approaches at the interface of quantitative and experimental cell biology while another module involved undergraduates in exploring the primary literature on the same topics. These efforts would not have been made possible without the support of the NSF EAGER grant.
